001package org.consensusj.analytics.util.collector;
002
003
004import java.util.Set;
005import java.util.function.BiConsumer;
006import java.util.function.BinaryOperator;
007import java.util.function.Function;
008import java.util.function.Supplier;
009import java.util.stream.Collector;
010
011/**
012 * Collector that collects the {@code n} objects containing the "largest slices" of an input stream of
013 * type {@code <E>}. Each object must have a numeric "slice size" of type {@code <N>} determined by a {@code sliceSizeExtractor}
014 * provided to the constructor. The result is a {@link LargestSliceList} containing the {@code n} largest slices
015 * ({@link LargestSliceList#getSliceList()}) and the sum of the slice sizes ({@link LargestSliceList#getTotalOther()}) of
016 * the filtered/excluded objects. The idea is the results can easily be converted to a Pie Chart.
017 * <p>
018 * The objects streamed must be unique, non-null, and a {@code sliceSizeExtractor} must be provided that
019 * will return a {@link Comparable} subclass of {@link Number}. The internal {@link LargestSliceAccumulator} is
020 * a mutable implementation of {@link LargestSliceList}
021 * <p>
022 * Note: Be careful to use only a single {@code sliceSizeExtractor} or you can end up with {@link LargestSliceList} objects
023 * with incompatible search orders (comparators).
024 * 
025 * @param <E> The type of objects
026 * @param <N> The subclass of {@link Number} to use, must be {@link Comparable}
027 */
028public class LargestSliceCollector<E, N extends Number & Comparable<? super N>>
029        implements Collector<E, LargestSliceAccumulator<E, N>, LargestSliceList<E, N>> {
030    private final int n;   // Maximum number to track
031    private final N zero;
032    private final Function<E, N> sliceSizeExtractor;
033    private final BinaryOperator<N> additionOperator;
034    
035    /**
036     * Construct a {@code LargestSliceCollector} to collect {@code n} objects of type {@code <E>}. The remaining
037     * constructor parameters provide support for the necessary internal calculations for types {@code <E>} and {@code <N>}.
038     *
039     * @param n Number of "slices" to collect
040     * @param sliceSizeExtractor A {@link Function} to return the slice size of an object
041     * @param zero The value of zero for type N
042     * @param additionOperator addition operator for type N
043     */
044    public LargestSliceCollector(int n, Function<E, N> sliceSizeExtractor, N zero, BinaryOperator<N> additionOperator) {
045        this.n = n;
046        this.sliceSizeExtractor = sliceSizeExtractor;
047        this.zero = zero;
048        this.additionOperator = additionOperator;
049    }
050
051    @Override
052    public Supplier<LargestSliceAccumulator<E, N>> supplier() {
053        return () -> new LargestSliceAccumulator<>(n, sliceSizeExtractor, zero, additionOperator);
054    }
055
056    @Override
057    public BiConsumer<LargestSliceAccumulator<E, N>, E> accumulator() {
058        return LargestSliceAccumulator::accumulate;
059    }
060
061    @Override
062    public BinaryOperator<LargestSliceAccumulator<E, N>> combiner() {
063        return LargestSliceAccumulator::combine;
064    }
065
066
067    /**
068     * Return a finisher function.
069     *
070     * @return A finisher function
071     */
072    @Override
073    public Function<LargestSliceAccumulator<E, N>, LargestSliceList<E, N>> finisher() {
074        return (accum) -> new LargestSliceListImpl<>(accum.getSortedSliceList(), accum.getTotalOther());
075    }
076
077    /**
078     * Note that our accumulator won't work correctly <b>or</b> efficiently if a single accumulator
079     * is used from multiple threads. It works with parallel streams, but not with a CONCURRENT collector.
080     * See: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/22350288/parallel-streams-collectors-and-thread-safety
081     * 
082     * @return The characteristics of this collector.
083     */
084    @Override
085    public Set<Characteristics> characteristics() {
086        return Set.of(Characteristics.UNORDERED);
087    }
088}
